title: Principles of Curriculum and Instruction Design for Early Childhood Education
description: This course is designed for students to understand the principles of curriculum in early childhood education and how teachers can deliver their teaching in kindergarten classrooms. The major principles of curriculum theories and issues are highlighted for students to develop an ability of curriculum planning and implementation in the future. To strengthen student teachers’ professional knowledge, skills, and attitudes for designing and implementing activities for young children, the learning and teaching processes in early childhood education are also discussed.
outcome: At the end of this course, students are expected to: 1. Understand principles in curriculum and instruction in the kindergarten context; 2. Analyze models of and approaches to curriculum planning and implementation in kindergarten settings; 3. Apply learning and teaching strategies to design children’s learning activities and for classroom management in kindergarten settings; 4. Plan and organize a meaningful learning environment to support children’s holistic development.
syllabus: 1. Nature of curriculum studies and models of curriculum development 2. Principles of organizing the early childhood curriculum 3. Curriculum approaches in kindergarten settings 4. Curriculum planning for children’s holistic development 5. Creating a child-centred learning environment by using appropriate learning and teaching strategies

title: Teaching and Learning through Play in Early Childhood Education
description: This course aims to introduce the characteristics, theories and practices of play as a teaching and learning strategy in ECE. The participants will develop awareness of the importance of play in child development from theoretical and empirical perspectives, and acquire techniques to enhance the child's cognitive and language development, as well as arts and creativity performance through play-based activities. The course will also equip participants with knowledge and skills related to play activity design, play resources planning and the assessment of play.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, participants should be able to: 1. Understand the characteristics, theories and practices of play;2. Design and implement play activities to foster young children’s language, cognitive, social, emotional, and physical development;3. Develop resources for play activities; 4. Assess children's learning and development in play.
syllabus: The course will cover the following topics: Characteristics and classification of play; Classical and contemporary theories of play; Play and learning； Play and language development; Play and science education; Play and creative expression in art and music; Indoor and outdoor play; Play and technology; Play-based curriculum; Assessing play and children’s development.

title: Language and Literacy in the Early Years
description: This course aims at providing students with fundamental concepts of language and literacy in early childhood. Through exploring theories of children's early literacy, this course overviews language development and developmentally appropriate instruction in kindergarten curriculum for young children. It equips pre-service teachers with knowledge and skills in the design and implementation of teaching plans for language development, with a focus on listening, speaking, writing, and reading. Finally, this course enables students to appreciate the value of multimodal perspectives in children's emergent literacy and recognize the importance of the learning environment (such as the bilingual and multicultural learning environment of Hong Kong) in supporting children's language and literacy development.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, participants should be able to:  To recognize and analyse the theories of children's language development. To design appropriate teaching plans for facilitating children's learning of Chinese and English, with a focus on listening, speaking, writing, and reading. To appreciate the value of multimodal perspectives in children's emergent literacy.  To recognize the importance of the learning environment in supporting children's language and literacy development.
syllabus: Language development in early childhood Early language in a multimodal perspective  Emergent literacy curriculum/ activities for Chinese learning English as a second language for children Emergent literacy curriculum/ activities for English learning Non-Chinese speaking children in Hong Kong kindergarten settings

title: STEM Education and Early Math, Science Learning Experience
description: This course is designed to help participants understand STEM (Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics) education with a focus on foundational concepts in early mathematics and science. Participants will explore different approaches to developing appropriate learning activities to foster young children's cognitive development in mathematics and science domains. This course will cover learning theories, teaching methods and key learning trajectories for developing young children's concepts and knowledge in the following topics: counting, early geometry, measurement, patterning and ordering, comparison and classification, and topics in life science, physical science, earth and environmental science, engineering, technology and science applications. The course would also extend participants' awareness of STEM education by drawing substantially on theories and practices in ECE settings.

title: Foundations of Education
description: This course seeks to provide students with an overview of a variety of perspectives on education, so that students will have a general understanding of how philosophies underlying teaching and learning in early childhood could be practised against the broader economic, social, cultural, and historical context of Hong Kong. Students will be introduced to such educational foundations as the ideas about education, philosophy of education, epistemology of education (theories of educational knowledge), and sociology of education, and will also be taught a brief history of educational development in post-war Hong Kong. Through discussions and class activities, students are guided to grasp the fundamentals of education, understand the important ideas about teaching and learning, and have an overview of related issues in education in general and early childhood education in particular.
outcome: To enable students: 1. to grasp the essence of some fundamental concepts, perspectives, and theories in the field of education 2. to apply these concepts, perspectives, and theories in examining the situation of early childhood education in Hong Kong 3. to understand the practical implications of such views and practices for early childhood education practitioners
syllabus: 1. Introduction 2. Ideas of education 3. History of education in post-war Hong Kong – esp the emergence of early childhood education 4. Knowledge and Curriculum 5. Curriculum and Early Childhood Education 6. Teaching and Teachers 7. Learning and Educational Psychology 8. Diversification of learners’ needs 9. Teacher training in Hong Kong 10. Social roles of Education 11. Educational inequality 12. Group presentations 13. Conclusion

title: Psychological Development of Young Children
description: This course will discuss the psychological development of humans and focus on the period of early childhood up to about six years old. It will offer a survey of different important subfields, such as the development of the nervous system and the brain, perceptual abilities, cognitive abilities, social abilities, language, intelligence, personality and atypical development. Emphases will be put on the scientific methodology adopted by psychologists, major theories and key concepts, and the integration of theories and applications in real-world scenario.
outcome: Upon completion of this course, you are expected to be able to: 1. Understand key concepts and major theories related to the psychological development of young children; 2. Understand children’s perspective based on psychological knowledge; 3. Develop critical thinking skills in analyzing developmental phenomena related to young children; 4. Apply and relate psychology to real-world issues related to young children
syllabus: 1. Issues in developmental studies 2. Prenatal development and early infancy 3. The brain and the nervous system 4. Perceptual development 5. Cognitive development 6. Intelligence and individual differences 7. Language development 8. Personality development 9. Social development 10. Stress and health 11. Atypical development Please refer to the course outline of respective teacher for details
required_readings: Required readings (if any) would depend on individual instructors. 1. Boyd, D. G., & Bee, H. L. (2014). The Developing Child (International Edition). Essex, UK: Pearson.

title: Social and Emotional Development of Young Children
description: Fear, anger, sadness, love and attachment, joy and happiness. How have these basic human emotions evolved? How do children acquire and express these emotions, and how do they affect child development? This course covers a wide range of theories, perspectives, and practices on the social and emotional development of children from infancy through the sixth year, with particular focus on family, schools, and culture as sources of socialization. Special attention will be given to the practical implications of the related behavioural and emotional problems often found among school children. These include aggression, social anxiety, oppositional behaviour, and other internalizing and externalizing difficulties. These topics will be presented with a practical focus on helping children with these and other social-emotional problems.
outcome: At the end of the course, students should be able to: 1. Compare and contrast the different theoretical perspectives that explain various aspects of children’s social and emotional development. 2. Demonstrate understanding of the cultural, family, and school contexts that shape children’s social and emotional development. 3. Cultivate their abilities in the application, analysis, synthesis, and evaluation of related knowledge. 4. Enhance their sensitivity to atypical development in children’s social and emotional functioning,
syllabus: 1. Theories of social-emotional development (biological, cognitive, and sociocultural perspectives) 2. Attachment and abuse 3. Social cognition: Understanding self and others 4. Functions of play 5. Atypical social-cognitive development 6. Biological and behavioral bases of self-regulation 7. Autonomy and compliance 8. Development of intentional communication 9. Aggression 10. Moral emotions, empathy, and prosocial behavior 11. Emotion expression and emotion regulation 12. Atypical emotional development

title: Physical and Motor Development of Young Children
description: This course will discuss current policies and issues related to young children’ physical and motor development across regions, as well as knowledge and skills developed by research and theories on movements concepts of gross motor skills and fundamental movement skills, which are essentials to our students who engage in early childhood education in the future. A developmentally appropriate curriculum for young children provides experiences which encourage development in the psychomotor, affective, and cognitive areas. The content of physical education in early childhood education program consists of both fundamental motor skills and movement concepts. Acquiring these basic movement patterns increases a child’s potential for learning more advanced sport skills and lifetime physical activities.
outcome: Upon completion of this course, you are expected to be able to: 1. familiarize curriculum guidelines on physical and motor skill domains of early childhood education recommended by education departments across regions 2. understand students’ growth and development in physical and motor skill domains 3. develop the visions on up to date teaching strategies and curriculums for young children 4. develop skills and knowledge in teaching movement concepts, gross motor skills and fundamental movement skills for young children 5. understand and apply various developmental theories into practices 6. design age- and developmental-appropriate curriculums and activities for developing young children’s physical and motor skills 7. learn safety protocols for teaching young children’s physical activities 8. develop innovative thinking for designing motivational learning activities 9. be able to develop self-reflection skills throughout the learning process 10. develop professional manner and positive attitudes for teaching young children in kindergartens (code of ethics)

title: Health, Nutrition and Safety for Young Children
description: This course provides a comprehensive overview of health, safety and nutritional needs of young children. There will be discussion on theoretical rationale, guidelines and strategies to meet these needs of young children in childcare and school settings. Topics to be discussed include: personal hygiene, common childhood diseases, preventing and responding to emergencies, planning learning experiences on health education, communication with parents, as well as child abuse and neglect.
outcome: By the end of the course, students are expected to be able to: 1. State common illnesses among young children and describe the screening procedures to assess a child’s health status 2. Identify sources of nutrients and appropriate meal planning 3. Describe health and safety regulations required for child care and kindergarten settings 4. Explain the role of the teachers in identifying suspected child abuse and/or neglect
syllabus: 1. nature and scope of health care education in early childhood 2. concepts of health; strategies to promote children’s holistic health 3. personal hygiene for working with young children 4. safety, common illnesses and infectious diseases and promoting safety in home, at school and in the community for young children 5. basic concepts in nutrition education, healthy living styles, and oral health for young children 6. The strategies of developing and evaluation of health related activities/ curriculum 7. environmental safety: causes of common accidents in preschool settings; basic principles in handling injuries 8. child protection: characteristics of maltreatment; procedure in handling suspected cases of child abuse

title: Classroom Communication for Early Childhood Teachers
description: This course is designed for students to understand the philosophy and practical application of classroom dialogues in early childhood classrooms. The details of conversation of the everyday activities of child-teacher interaction and the ways of interpreting each other's messages in terms of the interactional context through explicit and implicit communication are covered. Dialogic episodes of teaching and learning in play and activities in various teaching approaches are discussed, and strategies of effective classroom communication for early childhood teachers are highlighted.

title: Inclusive Education in Early Childhood Settings
description: This course aims at exploring the concepts and issues of inclusive education in Hong Kong kindergartens by providing an overview of theories and practices in early childhood inclusive education, as well as the inclusive education services in Hong Kong. This course equips participants with knowledge of behavioural characteristics of children with special needs, enabling them to refer student cases to various kinds of professionals in school settings, e.g. psychologists, therapists or social workers. Participants will learn about the application of teaching strategies in an inclusive classroom and the design of an inclusive curriculum to accommodate different learning needs of young children in kindergartens. The course also emphasizes the importance of home-school collaboration as pivotal to inclusive education in kindergartens.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, participants should be able to:  To evaluate implementation of inclusive education in Hong Kong kindergartens by using relevant theories. To discuss and analyse the behavioural characteristics of children with special needs. To apply appropriate teaching strategies of inclusive education. To design an inclusive curriculum for accommodating children's learning diversities. To value the importance of home-school collaboration as pivotal to inclusive education in kindergartens.
syllabus: Background and philosophy of inclusive education  Inclusive education services in Hong Kong Behavioral characteristics of children with different learning diversities  Teaching strategies for early childhood inclusive classrooms Curriculum planning for early childhood inclusive education Home-school collaboration for inclusive education

title: Early Childhood Education Policy and Practices in Hong Kong
description: This course aims to help prospective teachers to gain an understanding of the Hong Kong early childhood education services in relation to their occupational well-being and working environment. It is designed to provide prospective teachers with analytical tools to comprehend and review educational policies and their implementation in early childhood settings. Educational issues and policies in Hong Kong will be analyzed from an international-comparative perspective and a local concern for efficiency and equity. Topics for analysis may include: (1) early childhood education curriculum reform in Hong Kong since 1980s (2) pre-primary education voucher scheme; (3) school quality and governance; (4) learner diversity; (5) teacher education and qualification; and (6) health and safety issues in early childhood education.
outcome: After completing the course, students should be able to: 1. demonstrate an understanding of major issues and their underlying rationale and problems with reference to early childhood education in Hong Kong; 2. review issues related to early childhood education and their implications, and make informed judgments on such issues; 3. develop an understanding of policy and practices of schools and functions of schools from various perspectives; and 4. analyze how policies are made and consultations are conducted in early childhood settings in Hong Kong.
syllabus: 1. Curriculum reform in early childhood education; 2. Voucher scheme; 3. School quality and governance; and 4. Health and safety issues in early childhood education 5. Current topics in early childhood education by guest speakers

title: Multicultural Early Years Education in Hong Kong
description: Children from low-income, immigrant and ethnic minority are the fast growing groups in early years’ education. As such, this course aims to equip students with the essential knowledge, skills and attitudes to enhance the learning effectiveness of children from diverse cultural backgrounds. Students will be: (a) examining international perspectives on multicultural early years’ education; (b) engaging in dialogues with serving kindergarten personnel and families of diverse cultural backgrounds to deepen their understanding of the critical issues and challenges in fostering multicultural early childhood education; (c) applying culturally relevant pedagogy and approaches to foster an equitable and inclusive learning environment for all preschoolers from kindergartens to primary schools; (d) critically reflecting on the prevailing policies and provisions in early years and provide suggestions to address the problems; and (e) appreciating culturally responsive home-school collaboration to positively engage multicultural families in their children’s kindergartens to primary.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, participants should be able to:  Employ a critical lens of multiculturalism to address the learning and teaching issues in early years; Effectively apply culturally relevant pedagogy in promoting positive engagement of both mainstream and non-mainstream young children from early years to primary schooling; Demonstrate intercultural competence in working with parents from diverse cultural backgrounds; Critically analyse the policy documents and provision relating to enhancing multicultural early years education;  Foster an equitable and inclusive learning environment for holistic engagement of early years within the Hong Kong context.
syllabus: International perspectives on multicultural early years’ education. Issues and challenges in multicultural early years’ education (class, race, religion, equity, social justice etc.). Community engagement and/or field study to develop the essential knowledge, skills and attitudes towards young children with diverse cultural backgrounds in Hong Kong. Policy analysis on enhancing multicultural early years education in Hong Kong. Critical reflection on culturally relevant pedagogy and curriculum in early years e.g. multimodal languages, story-approach, technology-based. Appreciation of culturally responsive family engagement to enhance the learning outcomes of children from low income, Chinese immigrant and ethnic minority backgrounds.

title: Teaching Practice I
description: This course is designed for students to prepare to be professional and quality kindergarten teachers in the Hong Kong context. Students are required to design, implement and evaluate their learning activities to children aged 2 to 6. The learning activities should be integrated with the six domains emphasized in the Kindergarten Education Curriculum Guide. Developmentally appropriate practices with professional teachers’ knowledge, skills and attitude are expected to be delivered in the kindergarten classrooms. In this course, basic strategies of classroom observation, environment setting and daily operation are also introduced.

title: Teaching Practice II
description: This course is designed for students to deepen their professional knowledge, skills and attitude based on what they learnt from the Teaching Practice I. On top of designing, implementation and evaluating the integrated activities for young children, students are required to conduct their classroom teaching through observation, assessment and reflection. In this course, the rationale of “assessment inform teaching” is highlighted. Students have to identify a problem in their classrooms and then design tailor-made classes based on theories and approaches which they have learnt in the programme. The concepts and practices on evaluation and reflection of the classroom teaching performance are emphasized. Students are expected to apply advanced strategies of classroom management and environment setting to respond to their teaching reflections.

title: Teaching Strategies for Young Children with Special Educational Needs
description: This course is to equip students with in-depth knowledge and skills to work with individual children in special child care settings. The focus is on developing strategies and individualized educational plan to meet children’s developmental needs. Specific training models and programmes for working with special needs children are evaluated. There is also a discussion on working collaboratively with members in a multidisciplinary team.

title: Research Project
description: Students will work individually to pursue independent study on approved topics and areas under the supervision of teachers appointed by the Department/Faculty of Education.
